conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to understand how shadows cast by objects change when the light source moves.
Specifically, we want to determine how the positions and sizes of shadows A, B, C, and D would be affected if the light source moves backward.
Shadows are formed when an object blocks the light from reaching a surface. The shape and size of the shadow depend on the position of the light source relative to the object.
When the light source is closer to the object, the shadow is larger because the light rays spread out more. Conversely, when the light source is farther away, the shadow becomes smaller.
If the light source moves backward (away from the objects), it effectively increases the distance between the light source and the objects. This will cause the shadows to become smaller.

As the light source moves backward, the direction of the light rays becomes more parallel. This means that the shadows will shift slightly but not drastically change their position unless the objects themselves move or the angle of the light changes significantly.
Since the objects remain stationary and the light source only moves backward, the position of the shadows should remain relatively unchanged.
Increasing the distance between the light source and the objects causes the shadows to shrink. Therefore, shadows A, B, C, and D will all become smaller.
Comparing the first image with the second image, we can see that the shadows indeed appear smaller in the second image.
Shadow A (circular object) is smaller and more defined.
Shadow B (blocky object) is smaller and less elongated.
Shadow D (arrow-shaped object) is smaller and less spread out.
When the light source moves backward above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will become smaller in size but their positions will remain largely unchanged.
